intro: Rhynchospora hieronymi subsp. montevidensis, commonly known as the Montevideo sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to South America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its inflorescence consists of spikelets arranged in a dense, cylindrical cluster, characteristic of many sedges. The species is notable for its ecological role in stabilizing wetland habitats and supporting local biodiversity.
